title: Wisdom and Relationships
shortSummary: Proverbs 17 offers practical wisdom on living a righteous and peaceful life, emphasizing the value of humility, wise speech, and loving relationships. It contrasts folly and wisdom, highlighting the consequences of strife, dishonesty, and foolishness while encouraging love, understanding, and self-control.

keyCharacters.name: Wise Servant
keyCharacters.description: A servant who demonstrates wisdom and gains authority even over a shameful son, illustrating the value of wisdom over birthright (verse 2).

keyCharacters.name: Fool
keyCharacters.description: A recurring figure representing those who reject wisdom, act foolishly, and cause strife or sorrow (verses 7, 10, 12, 16, 21, 24, 28).

keyCharacters.name: Friend/Brother
keyCharacters.description: Figures representing faithful relationships and support during adversity, emphasizing the importance of loyalty and love (verse 17).

definitions.definition: A vessel used to purify silver by melting and removing impurities, symbolizing God's testing of the heart (verse 3).
A person who guarantees another's debt or obligation, often leading to financial risk or folly if done without understanding (verse 18).
Stubbornly contrary or perverse in behavior or attitude, leading to trouble and mischief (verse 20).
Correction or rebuke intended to guide someone toward wisdom and better behavior (verse 10).

outline.heading: The Value of Peace and Wisdom
outline.description: This section contrasts peaceful contentment with strife-filled abundance, highlights the authority of wisdom over shameful birthright, and reminds that God tests the heart while warning against wickedness and mockery.

outline.heading: Family and Social Relationships
outline.description: Focuses on the honor of family generations, the importance of truthful speech, the power of forgiveness, and the dangers of strife and unjust judgment.

outline.heading: Folly and Its Consequences
outline.description: Describes the foolishness of seeking wisdom without heart, the joy of true friendship, the harm of rash promises, and the destructive nature of a perverse heart and tongue.

outline.heading: Wisdom in Speech and Conduct
outline.description: Emphasizes the value of understanding and self-control in speech, the grief caused by foolish children, and the wisdom found even in a silent fool.

application: Pursue peace and contentment in your daily life rather than seeking material abundance that breeds conflict.
Practice forgiveness and cover offenses to maintain loving and lasting relationships.
Be slow to speak and quick to listen, allowing wisdom and understanding to guide your words.
Value and cultivate faithful friendships and family bonds, especially during times of adversity.

keyVerses.text: Better is a dry morsel, and quietness therewith, than an house full of sacrifices with strife.
keyVerses.significance: This verse teaches that peace and contentment are more valuable than abundance accompanied by conflict.

keyVerses.text: A friend loveth at all times, and a brother is born for adversity.
keyVerses.significance: It highlights the steadfast love of true friends and the purpose of family support in difficult times.

keyVerses.text: A merry heart doeth good like a medicine: but a broken spirit drieth the bones.
keyVerses.significance: This verse reveals the healing power of joy and the destructive effect of despair on oneâ€™s well-being.

keyVerses.text: Even a fool, when he holdeth his peace, is counted wise: and he that shutteth his lips is esteemed a man of understanding.
keyVerses.significance: It underscores the wisdom found in restraint and the value of silence over foolish speech.
